conclusion: The problem involves determining the current I of the constant current source in an electromagnetic aircraft launch system based on the given parameters and setup.

Figure (1) shows a coil fixed to a mover that slides without friction on horizontal rails in a radial magnetic field. The system includes a constant current source, a switch S, and a fixed resistor R0.
Figure (2) shows the velocity-time (v-t) diagram of the mover, with key points t1, t2, and t3 marked.
The mover starts from rest, accelerates the aircraft to takeoff speed, detaches, and then returns to its initial position under a retraction force F and magnetic force.
The forces acting on the mover include the magnetic force F and the retraction force F = (800 - 10v) N.
The acceleration a of the mover can be expressed as a = F/m, where F = (800 - 10v) N and m = 5 kg.
The takeoff speed v1 is given as 80 m/s, and the acceleration a is derived from F = (800 - 10v) N.
Setting v = v1 = 80 m/s, the equation 800 - 10v = 5 * (800 - 10v)/5 is solved, leading to v = 40 m/s.
The time t2 when the aircraft detaches is determined using the acceleration a = (800 - 10v)/5 and setting v = 40 m/s.
The time t3 when the retraction force F is removed is calculated using the same acceleration formula and setting v = 40 m/s.
The current I of the constant current source is calculated using I = v/R0, where v = 40 m/s and R0 = 9.5 Î©.
